body_html: @colesbury I definitely agree. I couldn't find any files where the corresponding .h wasn't at the top, though. I did canonicalize some includes e.g. tensor.h -> torch/csrc/autograd/tensor.h, but otherwise I think the includes are ordered, except for when Python.h is included. I remember reading here that Python.h has to be first always because it re-defines some macros that affect the standard library and such.
body_text: @colesbury I definitely agree. I couldn't find any files where the corresponding .h wasn't at the top, though. I did canonicalize some includes e.g. tensor.h -> torch/csrc/autograd/tensor.h, but otherwise I think the includes are ordered, except for when Python.h is included. I remember reading here that Python.h has to be first always because it re-defines some macros that affect the standard library and such.
body: @colesbury I definitely agree. I couldn't find any files where the corresponding `.h` wasn't at the top, though. I did canonicalize some includes e.g. `tensor.h` -> `torch/csrc/autograd/tensor.h`, but otherwise I think the includes are ordered, except for when `Python.h` is included. I remember reading [here](https://github.com/pytorch/pytorch/blob/master/torch/csrc/README.md) that `Python.h` has to be first always because it re-defines some macros that affect the standard library and such.
